text: Many apologies for not being in touch sooner. I am super busy at the moment.
my work in vfx happened as a spin off from being a director. I know, it usually works the other way round, but hey-ho, I’ve never done things the way people expect them to be done.

When I was in the process of finishing my feature film, only one to date, I ended up kind of running a team of vfx artists. I’m a very hands on director, so I had started trying to teach myself Afetr Effects
I wasn’t good enough quickly enough so I ended up just directing artists who knew what they were doing.
This was happening in London and the post producer there thought I had  knack for running a vfx room and suggested I start a business in Scotland, which is where I live.
Realising that I could be in development for a long time with my next movie I decided to give it a whirl.

I managed to raise some money to train people to do vfx and from there I had a kind of instant company ready to go to work. That was 4 years ago and I now employ 12 people in various roles. You can understand why it’s been difficult to make another movie, employing 12 people takes up a lot of my resources.

So that was how I got into vfx. I’m probably quite unusual in the respect that I don’t really know a great deal about vfx, really I am running a company of people who know a lot about vfx. That’s a skillset you learn as a director and basically comes down to leadership.

As a director you have to guide people with skills you don’t have to create something that fits with the overall thing you’re trying to make, and that encompasses a number of departments as I’m sure you’re aware - camera, make-up, wardrobe, design, vfx, stunts, locations and on.
and of course you have to remember the actors.
There’s a lot to learn though, I’ve never run a company before so it’s been quite a steep learning curve.

If you’re interested in being a director I can tell you how I got started and the things I feel I would like to have done more of. And I think vfx is a good place to start, but you have to be constantly building an idea of how the machine works and how all the different jobs fit together to make the whole.
Learning that will really help you to become a professional and get people to trust you. It’ll also help you to manipulate the machine to create the things you want to.
It’s a super tough gig being a director, great fun and exhilarating and terrifying and heartbreaking all at once.
I remember being with a friend of mine who was directing a movie and him turning to me just as we started production and saying “welcome to the beautiful nightmare”, and that’s exactly what it is.
